revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-10 17:31:23.000000000', 'message': "Fix Py2/Py3 differences in write locking code

In Py2, a file object write method returns NoneType.

In Py3, a file object write method returns a count of
bytes written, which can be used to interpret success.

As this code, at least for now, still needs to work
on Py2 without raising what appears to be errors, we
need to remove the assumption that data is returned
upon write.

Should a write fail, IOError is still raised in Py2,
which means the existing exception handling should be
sufficent.

Also, added an explicit flush for before we release the file
lock, just to ensure that the data is actually written out of
python's buffers before the lock is released.

Change-Id: I1cae8f1cd2f7da39600d72a84fe041ff0a97e580
Closes-Bug: #1741035
"}, {'created': '2018-01-10 22:04:50.000000000', 'message': "Fix Py2/Py3 differences in write locking code

In Py2, a file object write method returns NoneType.

In Py3, a file object write method returns a count of
bytes written, which can be used to interpret success.

As this code, at least for now, still needs to work
on Py2 without raising what appears to be errors, we
need to remove the assumption that data is returned
upon write.

Should a write fail, IOError is still raised in Py2,
which means the existing exception handling should be
sufficent.

Also, added an explicit flush for before we release the file
lock, just to ensure that the data is actually written out of
python's buffers before the lock is released.

Change-Id: I1cae8f1cd2f7da39600d72a84fe041ff0a97e580
Closes-Bug: #1741035
"}, {'created': '2018-01-11 14:42:58.000000000', 'message': "Fix Py2/Py3 differences in write locking code

In Py2, a file object write method returns NoneType.

In Py3, a file object write method returns a count of
bytes written, which can be used to interpret success.

As this code, at least for now, still needs to work
on Py2 without raising what appears to be errors, we
need to remove the assumption that data is returned
upon write.

Should a write fail, IOError is still raised in Py2,
which means the existing exception handling should be
sufficent.

Also, added an explicit flush for before we release the file
lock, just to ensure that the data is actually written out of
python's buffers before the lock is released.

Change-Id: I1cae8f1cd2f7da39600d72a84fe041ff0a97e580
Closes-Bug: #1741035
"}]
commit_message:
Fix Py2/Py3 differences in write locking code

In Py2, a file object write method returns NoneType.

In Py3, a file object write method returns a count of
bytes written, which can be used to interpret success.

As this code, at least for now, still needs to work
on Py2 without raising what appears to be errors, we
need to remove the assumption that data is returned
upon write.

Should a write fail, IOError is still raised in Py2,
which means the existing exception handling should be
sufficent.

Also, added an explicit flush for before we release the file
lock, just to ensure that the data is actually written out of
python's buffers before the lock is released.

Change-Id: I1cae8f1cd2f7da39600d72a84fe041ff0a97e580
Closes-Bug: #1741035

commit_message:
Remove deprecated MigrationManager.list cell_name kwarg

The cell_name kwarg was deprecated in Pike:

I54468682d5391668a513e708e26bc3c165c95ca1

And the CLI option was removed earlier in Queens (not yet
released):

I5d11eda2a6b35de98f0484492f597a87df882013

But that change forgot about the python API binding code
so this change removes that as well and updates the release
note.

Change-Id: I0cf808eaf7df80e221b412d2374b81fd402bd037
Closes-Bug: #1668743

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-11 21:00:07.000000000', 'message': 'Fix being able to create a reno using tox -e venv

Iace251446bafbd8963bc5a073de50ade583f6e46 moved the
reno dependency to a new requirements file which broke
the ability to create a release note using:

  tox -e venv -- reno new <slug>

This fixes it by adding the doc/requirements into the
venv tox environment.

Change-Id: I243d4d5148964511a83855d2b1b451aa1543b98b
'}]
commit_message:
Fix being able to create a reno using tox -e venv

Iace251446bafbd8963bc5a073de50ade583f6e46 moved the
reno dependency to a new requirements file which broke
the ability to create a release note using:

  tox -e venv -- reno new <slug>

This fixes it by adding the doc/requirements into the
venv tox environment.

Change-Id: I243d4d5148964511a83855d2b1b451aa1543b98b

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Migrate to override_role for network test_networks_rbac

Now that override_role has supplanted switch_role (which has
been deprecated) in [0], the RBAC tests need to switch to use
override_role.This PS switches to override_role for the network test
test_networks_rbac.

[0] I670fba358bf321eae0d22d18cea6d2f530f00716

Partially Implements: blueprint rbac-utils-contextmanager

Change-Id: I8a90f63aa488d37a1b779ab1d0c00c031c356e81

commit_message:
Creates policy.json

The default policy.json was removed in Pike. Creates a policy.json with
an empty json; augeas json lens fail if it is just an empty file.

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-21 22:55:22.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid always loading nested stack on update

Previously, when calling StackResource._validate_nested_resources() (which
we do whenever we create or update a nested stack), we would load the
nested stack into memory to validate the number of resources in the nested
stack, unless the max_resources_per_stack config option was set to -1. This
meant we would load the nested stack into memory in the same engine as the
parent on every update.

To reduce the memory high-water mark, fetch the information we need over
RPC from another engine instead.

To ensure this is only called once, move the call into the validate code.
(Previously it was called again in the create/update itself.)

Change-Id: I78d12ecc8240c697e26893ae2d7172b60883fb93
Partial-Bug: #1731349
'}, {'created': '2018-01-08 23:20:20.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid always loading nested stack on update

Previously, when calling StackResource._validate_nested_resources() (which
we do whenever we create or update a nested stack), we would load the
nested stack into memory to validate the number of resources in the nested
stack, unless the max_resources_per_stack config option was set to -1. This
meant we would load the nested stack into memory in the same engine as the
parent on every update.

To reduce the memory high-water mark, fetch the information we need over
RPC from another engine instead.

To ensure this is only called once, move the call into the validate code.
(Previously it was called again in the create/update itself.)

Change-Id: I78d12ecc8240c697e26893ae2d7172b60883fb93
Partial-Bug: #1731349
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid always loading nested stack on update

Previously, when calling StackResource._validate_nested_resources() (which
we do whenever we create or update a nested stack), we would load the
nested stack into memory to validate the number of resources in the nested
stack, unless the max_resources_per_stack config option was set to -1. This
meant we would load the nested stack into memory in the same engine as the
parent on every update.

To reduce the memory high-water mark, fetch the information we need over
RPC from another engine instead.

To ensure this is only called once, move the call into the validate code.
(Previously it was called again in the create/update itself.)

Change-Id: I78d12ecc8240c697e26893ae2d7172b60883fb93
Partial-Bug: #1731349

commit_message:
Add prometheus annotations to helm-toolkit

This adds the prometheus pod and service annotations to helm
toolkit, which allows for using prometheus's kubernetes service
discovery mechanisms for osh pods and service metrics as needed

Change-Id: I0e080d960553381014c4fd4f2bb6c83652241b0b

commit_message:
Generate a default keypair for nova.

This was missing from the post configuration.  Need a default keypair
for CI.

Change-Id: I12dfd2fc089257735d7322d2431999e88a5473c7

commit_message:
Ignore .eggs from git

This started popping up on my machine when installing this project as
editable (`pip install -e`). Ignore it, we clearly don't want it.

Change-Id: Idf520e3d274460bd820a16b52047f47e8ac47913

commit_message:
Add unit tests for neutron utils, add model/util for floating_ip

Floating IP model isn't used yet in-tree, but the conversion is tested,
and it could be used by various drivers (it is already used by the FLIP
driver).

Change-Id: I5f54c5ea5e70ea03f830548d61a2afee205f7f63

commit_message:
Adds tags for inhibit and silence

The new silence and inhibit rules will include tags on the alarm
that can be queried via the api. For more information and
documentation see: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/466403

Change-Id: I85b8bfc9338ee17709ec30aeb4b807b3bc12404e

commit_message:
Remove extraneous publish jobs from gertty

Gertty does not send release announcements, and it also doesn't
seem particularly important to sync the wheel mirrors.

Change-Id: I2caff68a6b2bca83f25245bdb750d96f13d575d1

commit_message:
Make daemon wait for VIF to become active

Currently CNI daemon is not coded to wait for VIF to become active
before returning IP to the CNI. This commit fixes that by adding waiting
to ADD part of the code.

Change-Id: I2a4c3f3534c54ee7da886c28f73b3dda236b9c93
Closes-Bug: 1739014

subject: Fix codec error when format=csv
messages: [{'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2017-12-06 13:15:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2017-12-06 13:58:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 8116, 'date': '2017-12-06 15:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2017-12-13 16:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-01-11 13:53:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-11 18:40:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:\n\nrecheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-06 13:15:46.000000000', 'message': "Fix codec error when format=csv

The Py2 version of the csv module cannot accept unicode text. In Py2
we replaced the csv module with the unicodecsv module which encodes
unicode text prior to calling the standard Py2 csv module. Thus when
the cvs formatted output is emitted on stdout it is presented as a
encoded byte stream. But stdout has been replaced with a StreamWriter
which encodes to the desired encoding. The problem is the StreamWriter
attempts to encode all objects passed to it's write function,
including str objects. Instead it should only encode unicode text objects
and allow bytes to pass through unmodified.

This patch adds an override of the codecs.getwriter function which
only encodes unicode text objects. In addtion we pass the encoding
value obtained from the stream to the unicodecsv writer.

The patch fixes the codec error when outputing csv formated text that
contains a non-ASCII character. The unicodecsv implmentation will emit
byte encoded str objects to the stream. When the core StreamWriter
attempts to encode a str object Python will first promote the str
object to a unicode object. The promotion of str to unicode requires
the str bytes to be decoded. However the encoding associated with the
str object is not known therefore Python applies the default-encoding
which is ASCII. In the case where the str object contains utf-8
encoded non-ASCII characters a decoding error is raised. By not
attempting to encode a byte stream we avoid this error.

A more complete discussion of the above issues can be found here:

https://github.com/fedora-infra/kitchen/blob/develop/kitchen2/docs/unicode-frustrations.rst#frustration-4-now-it-doesnt-take-byte-strings

Conflicts:
    cliff/tests/test_app.py

Change-Id: I22b5ad8bf0e227ec75a2a36986f0487191f7cbc2
Closes-Bug: 1720115
Signed-off-by: John Dennis <jdennis@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit c61cc30060ca56257ca3504153578e02e68e7f0a)
"}, {'created': '2017-12-06 13:58:54.000000000', 'message': "Fix codec error when format=csv

The Py2 version of the csv module cannot accept unicode text. In Py2
we replaced the csv module with the unicodecsv module which encodes
unicode text prior to calling the standard Py2 csv module. Thus when
the cvs formatted output is emitted on stdout it is presented as a
encoded byte stream. But stdout has been replaced with a StreamWriter
which encodes to the desired encoding. The problem is the StreamWriter
attempts to encode all objects passed to it's write function,
including str objects. Instead it should only encode unicode text objects
and allow bytes to pass through unmodified.

This patch adds an override of the codecs.getwriter function which
only encodes unicode text objects. In addtion we pass the encoding
value obtained from the stream to the unicodecsv writer.

The patch fixes the codec error when outputing csv formated text that
contains a non-ASCII character. The unicodecsv implmentation will emit
byte encoded str objects to the stream. When the core StreamWriter
attempts to encode a str object Python will first promote the str
object to a unicode object. The promotion of str to unicode requires
the str bytes to be decoded. However the encoding associated with the
str object is not known therefore Python applies the default-encoding
which is ASCII. In the case where the str object contains utf-8
encoded non-ASCII characters a decoding error is raised. By not
attempting to encode a byte stream we avoid this error.

A more complete discussion of the above issues can be found here:

https://github.com/fedora-infra/kitchen/blob/develop/kitchen2/docs/unicode-frustrations.rst#frustration-4-now-it-doesnt-take-byte-strings

Conflicts:
    cliff/tests/test_app.py

Change-Id: I22b5ad8bf0e227ec75a2a36986f0487191f7cbc2
Closes-Bug: 1720115
Signed-off-by: John Dennis <jdennis@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit c61cc30060ca56257ca3504153578e02e68e7f0a)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix codec error when format=csv

The Py2 version of the csv module cannot accept unicode text. In Py2
we replaced the csv module with the unicodecsv module which encodes
unicode text prior to calling the standard Py2 csv module. Thus when
the cvs formatted output is emitted on stdout it is presented as a
encoded byte stream. But stdout has been replaced with a StreamWriter
which encodes to the desired encoding. The problem is the StreamWriter
attempts to encode all objects passed to it's write function,
including str objects. Instead it should only encode unicode text objects
and allow bytes to pass through unmodified.

This patch adds an override of the codecs.getwriter function which
only encodes unicode text objects. In addtion we pass the encoding
value obtained from the stream to the unicodecsv writer.

The patch fixes the codec error when outputing csv formated text that
contains a non-ASCII character. The unicodecsv implmentation will emit
byte encoded str objects to the stream. When the core StreamWriter
attempts to encode a str object Python will first promote the str
object to a unicode object. The promotion of str to unicode requires
the str bytes to be decoded. However the encoding associated with the
str object is not known therefore Python applies the default-encoding
which is ASCII. In the case where the str object contains utf-8
encoded non-ASCII characters a decoding error is raised. By not
attempting to encode a byte stream we avoid this error.

A more complete discussion of the above issues can be found here:

https://github.com/fedora-infra/kitchen/blob/develop/kitchen2/docs/unicode-frustrations.rst#frustration-4-now-it-doesnt-take-byte-strings

Conflicts:
    cliff/tests/test_app.py

Change-Id: I22b5ad8bf0e227ec75a2a36986f0487191f7cbc2
Closes-Bug: 1720115
Signed-off-by: John Dennis <jdennis@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit c61cc30060ca56257ca3504153578e02e68e7f0a)

commit_message:
Correct panko auth region

panko::auth::auth_region is hardcoded to use 'regionOne', making the
keystone region incorrect if someone alters it with a custom template.

This patch corrects this behaviour, utilizing KeystoneRegion.

Change-Id: I9c6b6e9ff098956bf640b88717da45fc1fd6a707
Closes-Bug: 1742201
Related-Bug: BZ1525729

[{'created': '2018-01-04 23:26:18.000000000', 'message': 'Use docker_config_scripts for puppet apply

There are some configuration applies that we need to do durring the
deployment. These currently live as manually constructed bash runs which

failures.  In order to reduce the duplicated code and simplify this
exeuction, this change creates a docker_puppet_run.sh

the docker services. This allows use to properly handle
--detailed-exitcodes while also reducing the amount of duplicated code
bits that we have within THT.

'}, {'created': '2018-01-09 02:30:14.000000000', 'message': 'Use docker_config_scripts for puppet apply

There are some configuration applies that we need to do during the
deployment. These currently live as manually constructed bash runs which
are missing the --detailed-exitcode handling to know when we have
failures.  In order to reduce the duplicated code and simplify this
exeuction, this change creates a docker_config_scripts with
docker_puppet_run.sh in containers-common that can be reused by any of
the docker services. This allows use to properly handle
--detailed-exitcodes while also reducing the amount of duplicated code
bits that we have within THT.

Additionally this change adds a new shared value for ContainersCommon to
pull the required volumes for the docker_puppet_apply.sh script into a
single place. Unfortunately the existing volumes from ContainersCommon
includes a mount for /etc/puppet to /etc/puppet which causes problems
because we need to be able to write out a hiera value.  The /etc/puppet
mount is needed for the bootstrap_host_exec function which is consumed
by various docker_config tasks but the mount conflicts with the puppet
apply logic being used.

Depends-On: I24e5e344b7f657ce5d42a7c7c45be7b5ed5e6445
Change-Id: Icf4a64ed76635e39bbb34c3a088c55e1f14fddca
Related-Bug: #1741345
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Use docker_config_scripts for puppet apply

There are some configuration applies that we need to do during the
deployment. These currently live as manually constructed bash runs which
are missing the --detailed-exitcode handling to know when we have
failures.  In order to reduce the duplicated code and simplify this
exeuction, this change creates a docker_config_scripts with
docker_puppet_run.sh in containers-common that can be reused by any of
the docker services. This allows use to properly handle
--detailed-exitcodes while also reducing the amount of duplicated code
bits that we have within THT.

Additionally this change adds a new shared value for ContainersCommon to
pull the required volumes for the docker_puppet_apply.sh script into a
single place. Unfortunately the existing volumes from ContainersCommon
includes a mount for /etc/puppet to /etc/puppet which causes problems
because we need to be able to write out a hiera value.  The /etc/puppet
mount is needed for the bootstrap_host_exec function which is consumed
by various docker_config tasks but the mount conflicts with the puppet
apply logic being used.

Depends-On: I24e5e344b7f657ce5d42a7c7c45be7b5ed5e6445
Change-Id: Icf4a64ed76635e39bbb34c3a088c55e1f14fddca
Related-Bug: #1741345
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
os-traits: queens release 0.5.0

This is most likely the GA version of os-traits for the queens
release and what we'd branch for stable/queens.

There are only 3 changes in this release. The minor version is
bumped because there are new minimum required package dependencies
in this release.

The release notes URL for the pike deliverable is also updated.

Change-Id: Ib0154ade88150523070bf8f63ace4fd23983b672

commit_message:
os-vif: queens release 1.8.0

This is the first and so far only release for os-vif
in the queens series. Unless something major is needed
before the queens non-client library freeze, this will
also be the version we GA and branch for stable/queens.

This change also updates the release notes URL for the
pike deliverable.

Change-Id: Idd7f635295aff6e46391b82e45b89ef79d6d6c05

commit_message:
kernel: allow to override modules & sysctl settings

Allow to easily personalize Kernel modules and sysctl settings with two new parameters.
ExtraKernelModules and ExtraSysctlSettings are dictionaries that will take precedence
over the defaults settings provided in the composable service.

Closes-Bug: #1742440
Change-Id: I9cd43331e5e9a6074cd47040c29815ca32c61693
(cherry picked from commit ec1be1f4cdb605ed70fde1b4b1f8e551319629bd)

commit_message:
Implement RbacUtilsMixin for base RBAC classes

This PS implements a RbacUtilsMixin mixin class in rbac_utils
module. This mixin is useful for doing basic Patrole setup in one
place. The mixin currently handles skipping tests if the flag
`[patrole] enable_rbac` is False and initializing rbac_utils
for each RBAC test.

Following changes have been made:
  * Implementation of RbacUtilsMixin
  * Associated unit tests
  * Refactor base RBAC classes to use the mixin
  * Trivial documentation changes

Change-Id: Ieaf19ccc8ce374b12af4c481a2bddcdbe86dedec

commit_message:
Add floating IP qos_policy actions

Now we can associate a qos policy to the floating IP, and
dissociate it. The commands are:

  $ openstack floating ip create --qos-policy ...
  $ openstack floating ip set --qos-policy ...
  $ openstack floating ip set --no-qos-policy ...
  $ openstack floating ip unset --qos-policy

These commands are based on the neutron change:
I4efe9e49d268dffeb3df4de4ea1780152218633b

Partially-Implements blueprint: floating-ip-rate-limit

Change-Id: I932b32f78cc5a2b53926feaec1a0b392cf7e8b57

subject: Migrate to override_role for network metering_labels tests
messages:
[{'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-01-11 06:13:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-11 06:13:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
Migrate to override_role for network metering_labels tests

Now that override_role has supplanted switch_role (which has
been deprecated) in [0], the RBAC tests need to switch to use
override_role.

This PS switches to override_role for the network test
test_metering_labels_rbac.

[0] I670fba358bf321eae0d22d18cea6d2f530f00716

Partially Implements: blueprint rbac-utils-contextmanager

Change-Id: Iccefa15039b5a2fccdce07aafca073cc79d7b917

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-09 15:12:02.000000000', 'message': 'Ignore release-test in aclmanager

The openstack/release-test repository ACL gets picked up by
aclmanager when it updates ACL. Add it to the exceptions list,
and make sure that the list is actually used.

Change-Id: I7735898f53eafca15a8b4bb19459c576dc254d4e
'}]
commit_message:
Ignore release-test in aclmanager

The openstack/release-test repository ACL gets picked up by
aclmanager when it updates ACL. Add it to the exceptions list,
and make sure that the list is actually used.

Change-Id: I7735898f53eafca15a8b4bb19459c576dc254d4e

(1 comment)

This is a question for my own education. Searching for uses of get_session in other projects, there are still a few. In particular networking-odl, which is a Stadium project, calls it here: https://github.com/openstack/networking-odl/blob/master/networking_odl/l3/l3_odl_v2.py#L154. Given that get_session was marked as deprecated since Ocata, can we just go ahead and remove it without worrying that it is being used in a Stadium project?'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-01-05 17:50:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

commit_message:
Cleaned up get_session

It's remnant of enginefacade migration that seems to be unused in the
tree and deprecated since Ocata.

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=SNAT_ROUTER_INTF_KEY%7CFLOATINGIP_AGENT_INTF_KEY%7CL3_AGENT_MODE_DVR_NO_EXTERNAL%7CDVR_SNAT_BOUND"}, {'account_id': 7016, 'date': '2017-10-04 19:47:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@boden while some of the constant variable have already been ported to neutron-lib, there is some leftovers that we defined in neutron/constants while the neutron-lib work was going on. For example a new agent_type that we introduced 'dvr_no_external' in pike and this was configured only in neutron/constants. 
The plan was to move this later to neutron-lib."}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2017-10-05 14:32:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I've mentioned this in other patches, but I don't have a problem moving common constants into lib. However I was hoping the priority was put on those that are consumed outside neutron.


In either case we'd still need a release note."}, {'account_id': 7016, 'date': '2017-10-11 22:01:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
DVR: Move DVR agent related constants to neutron-lib

Move DVR agent releated constants to neutron-lib because
there were certain agent mode constants that were recently
created and it should be moved to the neutron-lib.

Change-Id: Ieb9374f5483a0ab2306592ab901686ca374db1c8

subject: Add group to policy management
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-10 22:23:45.000000000', 'message': "Add group to policy management

The move of policy.json into code means the file may not exist. We've
added support to ensure that the file exists in the openstacklib but we
need to make sure the permissions are right for each service. This adds
the group information to the policies so it works right.

Depends-On: I26e8b1384f4f69712da9d06a4c565dfd1f17c9ed
Change-Id: Ic76f2f1d136a16d0bc0bf8221004b11996ff3373
Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Add group to policy management

The move of policy.json into code means the file may not exist. We've
added support to ensure that the file exists in the openstacklib but we
need to make sure the permissions are right for each service. This adds
the group information to the policies so it works right.

Depends-On: I26e8b1384f4f69712da9d06a4c565dfd1f17c9ed
Change-Id: Ic76f2f1d136a16d0bc0bf8221004b11996ff3373
Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-11 20:02:35.000000000', 'message': 'Add commit irrelevant files to tempest-full

Many projects were skipping this job when patches included
only non-functional changes, but zuul ignores those settings
when the job is added through templates.

This adds the commonly ignored changes from these projects
inside the template definition to avoid some unnecessary
runs.

Change-Id: I6ce094be98a066b4c7ef6a0b7687cf2beb171a13
'}]
commit_message:
Add commit irrelevant files to tempest-full

Many projects were skipping this job when patches included
only non-functional changes, but zuul ignores those settings
when the job is added through templates.

This adds the commonly ignored changes from these projects
inside the template definition to avoid some unnecessary
runs.

Change-Id: I6ce094be98a066b4c7ef6a0b7687cf2beb171a13

commit_message:
Improve unit testing scalability

The use of class members in unittest's TestCase derivatives
is discouraged, and the abundance of class members in the
testing code base has crippled the ability to add tests.

This patch addresses the scalability limitations by removing all class
members and relocates them in the relevant setUp function.

Change-Id: Ic0380a44749ea9bb506f67d876c3ecb7d363e726

[{'created': '2017-12-23 13:35:44.000000000', 'message': "Fix find() interface when attr is not specified

It seems to use None as the attr key and throws TypeError.
Let's not do the secondary search when attr is not specified.

commit_message:
Fix find() interface when attr is not specified

It seems to use None as the attr key and throws TypeError.
Let's not do the secondary search when attr is not specified.

Change-Id: Ic240d19f48d362ab74a91bace5eab31542823718
Closes-Bug: #1739882

commit_message:
Allow test runner to pick the number of workers

We are hopeful that the change will speed up the job so that it doesn't
hit default job timeout of ~3h, while also not destabilizing the gate.

Change-Id: I9f15a58298013bc9d14135169cf8d6b1538c3ce1
Closes-Bug: #1742200

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-10 09:35:23.000000000', 'message': "Use a venv with previous ansible version for upgrades

When doing the role upgrade, we run every playbook with current's
branch ansible. This is normal for the infrastructure bits (which
are running on current branch), but not for the installation of
the previous branch's role, which should use previous branch's
environment.

This commit adds:
- A new venv build script, containing the previous version of ansible
- A split between the infrastructure bits (running current ansible),
  the previous role run, and the upgrade of the role.

Change-Id: I91fe4e867750d7cee9ad7d84b005eb0231849df9
Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
Closes-Bug: #1741471
"}]
commit_message:
Use a venv with previous ansible version for upgrades

When doing the role upgrade, we run every playbook with current's
branch ansible. This is normal for the infrastructure bits (which
are running on current branch), but not for the installation of
the previous branch's role, which should use previous branch's
environment.

This commit adds:
- A new venv build script, containing the previous version of ansible
- A split between the infrastructure bits (running current ansible),
  the previous role run, and the upgrade of the role.

Change-Id: I91fe4e867750d7cee9ad7d84b005eb0231849df9
Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
Closes-Bug: #1741471

Remove the redundant attributes

DeleteInstance action inherits from tables.DeleteAction,
So remove the unused attributes.

Change-Id: I426820596c186cf216583014c6be0d57426fc10e

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > One question, see inline (same question in both places).

I guess config file wise it would not make a difference having them in the group or in the DEFAULT. AFAIK there is no way separating which options comes from which config file and even worse the config file parsing resolves duplicate entries very clearly by just overwriting anything with the latest provided.

For me it just makes easier to keep track of these when we don't try to overload the groups/values but if you feel strongly about it I'm fine for dropping the grouping."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-01-10 13:18:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Add hooks for Image Import plugins

This change adds hooks for pulling in plugins for
Interoperable Image Import taksflow. Boilerplate Noop
plugin is provided as an example and for testing.

Change-Id: If14c7dc4f38360006f9cb350fbba54fa2f33be61

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 17:01:23.000000000', 'message': 'Make _Provider really private

By design, nova.compute.provider_tree._Provider is intended to be
accessed only through ProviderTree interfaces to ensure thread safety.
However, certain ProviderTree methods were returning _Provider objects,
allowing callers to think it was okay to access their internals
directly.

With this change, we truly hide _Provider behind ProviderTree.  As long
as callers are well-behaved (accessing only public methods of public
classes), there is no longer any way to access _Provider internals.

Summary of the changes:

- ProviderTree.find is removed.
- ProviderTree.new_root and .new_child now return the UUID of the
  newly-created _Provider, rather than the _Provider itself.  (We return
  the UUID because it may have been generated; and there is currently no
  othre way for the caller to discover it.)

Note: It is possible that future changes will be necessary to provide
(read-only) access to some _Provider attributes.  No such accessors are
implemented herein.

Change-Id: If5eed34cb5a2cd94a6305a7626adfe7129119e44
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
'}, {'created': '2017-11-29 17:21:28.000000000', 'message': 'Make _Provider really private

commit_message:
Make _Provider really private

By design, nova.compute.provider_tree._Provider is intended to be
accessed only through ProviderTree interfaces to ensure thread safety.
However, certain ProviderTree methods were returning _Provider objects,
allowing callers to think it was okay to access their internals
directly.

With this change, we truly hide _Provider behind ProviderTree.  As long
as callers are well-behaved (accessing only public methods of public
classes), there is no longer any way to access _Provider internals.

Summary of the changes:

- ProviderTree.find is removed.
- ProviderTree.new_root and .new_child now return the UUID of the
  newly-created _Provider, rather than the _Provider itself.  (We return
  the UUID because it may have been generated; and there is currently no
  other way for the caller to discover it.)

Note: It is possible that future changes will be necessary to provide
(read-only) access to some _Provider attributes.  No such accessors are
implemented herein.

Change-Id: If5eed34cb5a2cd94a6305a7626adfe7129119e44

commit_message:
Use local owners module

Instead of pulling owners.py from the system-config repo, start
using the local copy provided by the openstack_election package.

Change-Id: I180ef0e5ec880b46f0427c1c952b640a780b5732

commit_message:
Import owners.py script from system-config

As a first step in simplifying election tooling, move the
openstack-infra/system-config:tools/owners.py into this repo. It
will be consumed in a later change, and eventually the routines
within it can be further decomposed and more tightly integrated into
the other tooling here.

Change-Id: Ie7ebe75f39f537d48e8e7190dd3659eddd168656

commit_message:
Download openshift binaries using curl in DevStack

This commit switches downloading of openshift binaries from wget to
curl. This is to prevent wget retrying the download from the redirection
URL instead of the original URL supplied on the command line. curl
behaves differently here, so it should solve our gate issues.

Closes-Bug: 1734875
Change-Id: Ic5ad80cc5ce53879853da156a24fd1c6cabf5080

commit_message:
Correct pluarity of "Python SDKs"

The titles and lead-in text make it sound like there is "one SDK" which
is not accurate. Rather, there is discussion of the various Python SDKs.

Change-Id: I923b54c43f581afb329e359cb38c59bf485e0183

commit_message:
Distinguish between cloud-wide and per-service apis

The two are different use cases, and we have things that focus on the
cloud-wide story. Lead with those, then show docs for individual
services that users can fallback to if they need to.

Update docs and update this for all branches that your the project-data
for language-bindings (pike and queens only).

Change-Id: Ib1f7b7c77ec2b9536c4a03425694a6300025a6c3

commit_message:
Change --http_method arg to --http-method

As in OSC, the convention is to use - to connect multiple words
arg, update the --http_method healthmonitor arg to --http-method.

Change-Id: I3372ca6d7c384090445fdb9004f05c678c8e25e2

commit_message:
WIP: libvirt: Use only existing mdevs if kernel race

There is an existing kernel race that prevents libvirt to be notified when
a new mediated device is created thru sysfs. As a result, it is impossible for
Nova to dynamically create those mdevs upon request.
The proposed workaround is to allow a flag to prevent the mdev creation and
rather just use a pool of pre-created mdevs (by the operator) as the only
resource for finding which one to allocate to an instance.

Note that the inventory isn't impacted since the operator should create all the
possible mdevs from a single capable physical device hence that device having
an 'availableInstances' value equal to 0.

TODO:
 - Unit tests.
 - Proof test on my box.

Change-Id: Ic644e38fc64dfcde0694ef7a170e6ea3825e2fb6
Partially-Implements: blueprint add-support-for-vgpu

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-08 13:50:49.000000000', 'message': "libvirt : Force a specificly static UUID for a mediated device

Since mediated devices are not persisted upon reboot with libvirt, we need a
way to consider non-dynamically generated UUIDs and rather use hashed UUIDs so
when we restart nova-compute, it can pass the same UUID for creating it again.

Fortunately, RFC4122 proposes 2 versions for our purpose: v3 and v5.
Let's take v3 (MD5 hash) and use it by generating an UUID based on the existing
instance UUID and the current index of the number of mediated devices we want
to create.

For example, say instance A uses 2 mediated devices in its guest configuration.
Instead of looking up the guest XML (which can be wrong in case of a hard
reboot for example), we can recreate the mediated devices by having the same
UUIDs.

Change-Id: Idd53bdfd620124f13b5bf4e1a0858b7a9e1d92db
Partially-Implements: blueprint add-support-for-vgpu
"}, {'created': '2018-01-10 21:04:31.000000000', 'message': "libvirt : Force a specificly static UUID for a mediated device

Let's take v3 (MD5 hash) and use it by generating an UUID based on the existing
instance UUID and the current index of the number of mediated devices we want

For example, say instance A uses 2 mediated devices in its guest configuration.
Instead of looking up the guest XML (which can be wrong in case of a hard

Partially-Implements: blueprint add-support-for-vgpu

commit_message:
libvirt : Force a specificly static UUID for a mediated device

Since mediated devices are not persisted upon reboot with libvirt, we need a
way to consider non-dynamically generated UUIDs and rather use hashed UUIDs so
when we restart nova-compute, it can pass the same UUID for creating it again.

Fortunately, RFC4122 proposes 2 versions for our purpose: v3 and v5.
Let's take v3 (MD5 hash) and use it by generating an UUID based on the existing
instance UUID and the current index of the number of mediated devices we want
to create.

For example, say instance A uses 2 mediated devices in its guest configuration.
Instead of looking up the guest XML (which can be wrong in case of a hard
reboot for example), we can recreate the mediated devices by having the same
UUIDs.

Change-Id: Idd53bdfd620124f13b5bf4e1a0858b7a9e1d92db
Partially-Implements: blueprint add-support-for-vgpu

commit_message:
Configure VIPs for all networks including composable networks

Configure all VIPs including those on custom composable networks.
Hard-coded network names are removed and instead a hiera parameter
containing all networks is used.

For keepalived, the vrouter_id is generated from an index for each
network in the hiera data.  This will change the vrouter_ids for
some VIPs.

Change-Id: I117454afe750451ad1f2633fa0f196bb71740b8d
Partial-Bug: 1741129
Depends-On: If8d3219a0714e3db34980e884dce84912a837865

commit_message:
Add composable network VIPs for puppet configuration

Adds new hiera parameters for VIPs for all isolated networks including
any custom composable networks.  The existing hard-coded network parameters
can be removed when the puppet-tripleo change
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/531037 merges that no longer uses them.

The new network_virtual_ips paramater contains the network name, vip, and
an index used to generate the vrouter_id in puppet-tripleo.

Change-Id: If8d3219a0714e3db34980e884dce84912a837865
Partial-Bug: 1741129

commit_message:
DMN: ceph multinode experiment

Recently we have started seeing failures in the multinode gates
for glance image creation while using the radosgw backend. This
PS experiments with some params to investigate potential impact.

Change-Id: Ibaa35ccebf0a9a50302f38b2b4f5cb9a016537bf

commit_message:
Configure cache when setting up docker_registry

We are currently configuring /etc/docker/daemon.json
with {} when installing docker.

This patch enables the cache when using a local docker
registry [1].

[1]: https://docs.docker.com/registry/recipes/mirror/#configure-the-cache

Change-Id: Ifd57d96f5fe634761064a6fd8a7dd68f8eccf942

subject: Implement create_mocks decorator to make mocks easier
messages:
[{'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2017-10-25 13:33:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2017-10-25 13:36:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2017-10-25 15:57:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-10-26 07:48:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I am not sure we need this kind of custom methods.
Can't we simply use with mock.patch(...) pattern?"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-10-26 07:49:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2017-10-26 08:32:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

"I am not sure we need this kind of custom methods.
Can't we simply use with mock.patch(...) pattern?"

I don't see any issues with custom methods(decorators) here.
'with mock.patch(...)' pattern doesn't look good when we need to make 3+ mocks. E.g. [1]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/b3833594da20a331425ccc152880a43338fcc9f1/cinder/tests/unit/backup/drivers/test_backup_ceph.py#L1296-L1314'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-10-26 09:30:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Your example from cinder is the old pattern of 'with' clause. It is the style of Python 2.6 era.

Python 2.7 and 3 allows nested arguments in 'with' clause.
The rewritten version of your example can be found at http://paste.openstack.org/show/624687/

One tricky point is a backslash is required.

I have no strong opinion and am okay with either way."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-12-20 19:36:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-08 15:47:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

During the work in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/531728/2/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/overview/tests.py, it turns out this is sometimes useful especially when mocked methods are used inside sub methods. It reduces the number of arguments a lot.
Let's move this forward."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-08 17:44:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-08 17:45:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-08 17:49:14.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from cinder-tests-mock-refactoring to bp/mock-framework-in-unit-tests'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-01-10 11:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Akihiro, thanks a lot for working on it! I appreciate your help'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-10 11:53:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-11 15:39:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

[{'created': '2018-01-11 13:41:36.000000000', 'message': "Remove infracloud-vanilla from nodepool

We lost the controller of infracloud-vanilla due to a bad HDD, since
we've agree to let the cloud die off, we can start to colapse the
existing compute nodes into chocolate.

Change-Id: I6f93ccd8a6bbcd5d83f2e8717426a1ed157d9734
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Remove infracloud-vanilla from nodepool

We lost the controller of infracloud-vanilla due to a bad HDD, since
we've agree to let the cloud die off, we can start to colapse the
existing compute nodes into chocolate.

Change-Id: I6f93ccd8a6bbcd5d83f2e8717426a1ed157d9734
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

ironic-python-agent needs dhcp-all-interfaces

The IPA image needs the DIB option dhcp-all-interfaces enabled.

Change-Id: I8f9ce65652c653b711fe8aaae6e32daaaee8178e

commit_message:
Grafana: support multiple replicas and data persistance

This PS adds support for multiple replicas of Grafana to be
deployed, and adds MySQL based data persistance to the chart.

Change-Id: Ife44985a6d5024cc2074346340fba1d8efdecbfa

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-09 16:10:56.000000000', 'message': "Fix ca_file and insecure usage

The 'ca_file' and 'insecure' configuration options
need to be processed together to determine the 'verify'
argument value when a keystoneauth1 Session is instantiated.

The 'cert' Session constructor argument was passed
incorrectly, as it pertains to the client certificate,
whereas the 'verify' argument pertains to the server
certificate.

Change-Id: Ie6d697c22ac9210c95b8006dd35963e0c836ac5c
Task: 6164
Story: 2001452
"}, {'created': '2018-01-09 16:26:47.000000000', 'message': "Fix ca_file and insecure usage

The 'ca_file' and 'insecure' configuration options
need to be processed together to determine the 'verify'
argument value when a keystoneauth1 Session is instantiated.

The 'cert' Session constructor argument was passed
incorrectly, as it pertains to the client certificate,
whereas the 'verify' argument pertains to the server
certificate.

Change-Id: Ie6d697c22ac9210c95b8006dd35963e0c836ac5c
Task: 6164
Story: 2001452
"}]
commit_message:
Fix ca_file and insecure usage

The 'ca_file' and 'insecure' configuration options
need to be processed together to determine the 'verify'
argument value when a keystoneauth1 Session is instantiated.

The 'cert' Session constructor argument was passed
incorrectly, as it pertains to the client certificate,
whereas the 'verify' argument pertains to the server
certificate.

Change-Id: Ie6d697c22ac9210c95b8006dd35963e0c836ac5c
Task: 6164
Story: 2001452

commit_message:
Add proxy doc

This patch set outlines troubleshooting details for operators
trying to use OpenStack-Helm behind a corporate firewall and
require the need of a proxy to reach the internet.

Change-Id: I6597a49cfbaa8f7e0461edf1298e724ba9dfe28b
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>

commit_message:
Switch to oslo_log

Trove dashboard is currently using python logging module to
implement logging functionality.
This patch made a switch to oslo.log(logging for openstack projects)

Reference:-
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.log

Change-Id: I92a417a7342f4f264e8a5ede52ba49f0b7475e6d
Closes-Bug: #1656167

I'm all for doing what's needed here but I think the approach that I was hearing was to remove centos and rhel dep on scsi-target-util usage all together."}, {'account_id': 19384, 'date': '2017-07-06 20:42:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

kolla version of iscsi lvm uses "iscsi_helper = tgtadm" which forces to use tgtd and tgtadm, I suspect if package scsi-target-utils removed it will break this functionality.'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2017-07-06 22:33:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Thierry or Jon,

Hey folks.  I support your objective of removal of EPEL and building RHEL containers.  That said, we cannot simply change the container contents, merge it, and call it a day.

The kolla-kubernetes gates rely heavily on LVM-ISCSI to run functional testing of the deployment.

Our other deployment deliverable, kolla-ansible has no gating at all on this functionality.

What we don't want to do is break this functionality and more importantly we need to protect the operational safety of the gate in kolla-kubernetes as it picks up all kinds of errors in the containers.  Unfortunately the kolla-kubernetes repo is not cross-repo gated with the kolla repo.  kolla-ansible is cross-repo gated, but lacks gates.

I'd +2 the intent of this change (the exact specifics need to go through a proper review which can be fasttracked) when following criteria are met:
1. lvm+iscsi cinder backend works properly in kolla-ansible deliverable with this container modification
2. no gates are broken with kolla-kubernetes with this container modification

When your ready to proceed doing the work, please contact me on irc.  I can help you get the patch into a format that will be testable in the kolla-kubernetes gate.  By testing in the kolla-kubernetes gate, I think you should be able to pretty quickly iterate on a solution for both kubernetes and the container contents that meet the requirements of "Remove EPEL + Run on RHEL OSP".  The gate will pick up any errors in programming pretty well.  The kolla-ansible gate however is a bit more leaky and will require manual testing.  

I know it this is a lot of work for the removal of one dependency.  I believe the investment is worth the effort.

The best way to contact me is sdake on irc.  You will need guidance with this work.

Regards
-steve'}, {'account_id': 10787, 'date': '2017-07-06 22:58:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

There is also important issue of upgrades. Today we have no-downtime upgrades for VMs. If VM loses access to storage due to this shift, that's bad. We need to make sure that existing volumes works and keeps working.

To me scenario that must succeed goes like that:
1. VM X has volume Y and writes constantly
2. We upgrade openstack (including cinder-vol container)
3. VM X can keep writing to volume Y
4. Volume Y can be re-attached to VM Z after upgrade

I'm ok if we won't be able to create or re-attach volumes during upgrade (then it's just release note that you need to call maintenance window during cinder update), but breatking existing volumes is huge no for me and we need to make sure it never happens."}, {'account_id': 19384, 'date': '2017-07-07 00:40:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hello,

I want to try to add lioadm helper support, but I need to understand how it works comparing to tgtd. Your help here would be greatly appreciated and it will help to unblock this PS.'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2017-07-07 02:03:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> There is also important issue of upgrades. Today we have
 > no-downtime upgrades for VMs. If VM loses access to storage due to
 > this shift, that's bad. We need to make sure that existing volumes
 > works and keeps working.
 > 
 > To me scenario that must succeed goes like that:
 > 1. VM X has volume Y and writes constantly
 > 2. We upgrade openstack (including cinder-vol container)
 > 3. VM X can keep writing to volume Y
 > 4. Volume Y can be re-attached to VM Z after upgrade
 > 
 > I'm ok if we won't be able to create or re-attach volumes during
 > upgrade (then it's just release note that you need to call
 > maintenance window during cinder update), but breatking existing
 > volumes is huge no for me and we need to make sure it never
 > happens.

I find it unlikely operators use this feature in production.  I think it makes sense to ping the operators list on this point, as doing what you ask (zero downtime upgrades for lvm scsi backed cinder volumes with a change of the underlying infrastructure) seems infeasible."}, {'account_id': 9061, 'date': '2017-07-07 15:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Only support lioadm for pike and beyond

scsi-target-utils doesn't exist on rhel7+
cinder devstack has switched over to lioadm

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/457875/

cinder does not use this package and this is legacy code

Change-Id: I0dee3d21c64a453d55d940e24a9a7e831d13cea8

(15 comments)

Thanks for the spec!

You can find here a few suggestions and questions.

As a summary, I'd be happy to see:
- More testing details (the HOW we test it)
- More deployment details (the WHERE)
- Minor typo fixes

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-01-04 12:47:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1

The spec is now clear. I vote positively for the inclusion of the change, now that it's clarified.

We won't have end to end testing, because no deployer infrastructure integration will be tested. What would be the success criteria? Just deploying with BGP? Don't you intend to prove it's working?"}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2018-01-04 16:32:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

What would be the success criteria? Just deploying with BGP? Don't you intend to prove it's working?
>> The success criteria would be testing establishing bgp neighborship between odl and dc-gw (it can be simulated with a vm installed with quagga) and exchange a route for ip prefix of a vrf instance. 
The plan is deploy this scenario with XCI+OSA and test this part in opnfv's sdnvpn project."}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-01-11 10:46:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> What would be the success criteria? Just deploying with BGP? Don't
 > you intend to prove it's working?
 > >> The success criteria would be testing establishing bgp
 > neighborship between odl and dc-gw (it can be simulated with a vm
 > installed with quagga) and exchange a route for ip prefix of a vrf
 > instance.
 > The plan is deploy this scenario with XCI+OSA and test this part in
 > opnfv's sdnvpn project.

Can this be tested outside of OPNFV/XCI? It is possible to have a CI job in OSA to verify that this is working? Or do we need OPNFV components for that?"}, {'account_id': 27552, 'date': '2018-01-11 10:55:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26445, 'date': '2018-01-11 11:10:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

>> Can this be tested outside of OPNFV/XCI? It is possible to have a CI job in OSA to verify that this is working? Or do we need OPNFV components for that?

Yes, we could make networking-bgpvpn tempest to be run as OSA CI job and it can be done in the neutron role (as part of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/522598/). But this doesn't cover actual quagga integration. this needs tenant network with VMs and quagga VM  to be setup which is a very complex setup and not a scope of OSA."}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-01-11 11:16:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2

> >> Can this be tested outside of OPNFV/XCI? It is possible to have
 > a CI job in OSA to verify that this is working? Or do we need OPNFV
 > components for that?
 > 
 > Yes, we could make networking-bgpvpn tempest to be run as OSA CI
 > job and it can be done in the neutron role (as part of
 > https://review.openstack.org/#/c/522598/). But this doesn't cover
 > actual quagga integration. this needs tenant network with VMs and
 > quagga VM  to be setup which is a very complex setup and not a
 > scope of OSA.

OK understood. Thank you"}, {'account_id': 538, 'date': '2018-01-11 13:51:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

oh dear god not more stuff in the deploy_utils module... I was really hoping that this refactor would result in a StandardDeployInterface with standard functions (because most of the logic should be the same) used by AgentDeploy and IscsiDeploy, not more unoverridable module level methods in deploy_utils...'}, {'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2018-01-10 18:33:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> oh dear god not more stuff in the deploy_utils module... I was
 > really hoping that this refactor would result in a
 > StandardDeployInterface with standard functions (because most of
 > the logic should be the same) used by AgentDeploy and IscsiDeploy,
 > not more unoverridable module level methods in deploy_utils...

Thanks for review Sam. Not sure why are they less overridable than the ones in base deploy interface, as if you write your own deploy interface, you can call those functions or not, same way as call base class methods or not. the only thing that would be differentis there would be no need to write a method at all if standard implementation works for you. apart from that, these are functions that accept parameters, so we can't base other interfaces from it, unless we change code in conductor.

I can create some mixin class tho if you prefer."}, {'account_id': 19339, 'date': '2018-01-11 03:39:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

'}, {'created': '2018-01-05 23:53:38.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor deploy interface methods

This change moves most of the common code for prepare, deploy and
tear_down methods of agent and iscsi deploy interfaces into the
deploy_utils module. Along the way, it fixes a couple of
inconsistencies described in the bug below.

Closes-Bug: #1735517

Change-Id: Iadd035cb59ccc1729f3ab3b7d61d667fedf8b6d6

'}, {'created': '2018-01-10 18:08:18.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor deploy interface methods

This change moves most of the common code for prepare, deploy,
tear_down and clean_up methods of agent and iscsi deploy
interfaces into the deploy_utils module.

Apart from that, iscsi deploy interface was triggering
boot.prepare_instance for nodes in ADOPTING state in the prepare method,
which in turn sets boot device. It should not be the case, as BMC of
ADOPTING nodes should not be accessed. Other things, like pxe config
switching, are necessary tho. On the other hand, agent deploy interface
was not calling boot.prepare_instance in prepare method for ADOPTING
nodes, so pxe configs did not get generated, but they should be, in case

Closes-Bug: #1735517

Change-Id: Iadd035cb59ccc1729f3ab3b7d61d667fedf8b6d6
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor deploy interface methods

This change moves most of the common code for prepare, deploy,
tear_down and clean_up methods of agent and iscsi deploy
interfaces into the deploy_utils module.

Apart from that, iscsi deploy interface was triggering
boot.prepare_instance for nodes in ADOPTING state in the prepare method,
which in turn sets boot device. It should not be the case, as BMC of
ADOPTING nodes should not be accessed. Other things, like pxe config
switching, are necessary tho. On the other hand, agent deploy interface
was not calling boot.prepare_instance in prepare method for ADOPTING
nodes, so pxe configs did not get generated, but they should be, in case
of iscsi or netboot. This patch also fixes these inconsistencies.

Closes-Bug: #1735517

Change-Id: Iadd035cb59ccc1729f3ab3b7d61d667fedf8b6d6

commit_message:
Switch non-vendor parts admin guide to hardware types

This change makes the admin guide use hardware types for examples and
explanations. The in-band inspection document was updated with recent
changes.

Vendor driver documentation requires more careful review, and ideally
should be updated by vendor representatives.

Change-Id: I98a2eb905e352502a7f9f4cb1804c9d64489ec47
Partial-Bug: #1690185

subject: Remove Neutron legacy jobs definition
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 748, 'name': 'Armando Migliaccio', 'email': 'armamig@gmail.com', 'username': 'armando-migliaccio'}, {'_account_id': 4694, 'name': 'Miguel Lavalle', 'email': 'miguel@mlavalle.com', 'username': 'minsel'}, {'_account_id': 6547, 'name': 'Andreas Jaeger', 'email': 'jaegerandi@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaegerandi'}, {'_account_id': 6854, 'name': 'YAMAMOTO Takashi', 'email': 'yamamoto@midokura.com', 'username': 'yamamoto'}, {'_account_id': 9061, 'name': 'David Moreau Simard', 'email': 'moi@dmsimard.com', 'username': 'dmsimard'}, {'_account_id': 9656, 'name': 'Ihar Hrachyshka', 'email': 'ihrachys@redhat.com', 'username': 'ihrachys'}, {'_account_id': 11975, 'name': 'Slawek Kaplonski', 'email': 'skaplons@redhat.com', 'username': 'slaweq'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2017-12-29 18:18:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2017-12-29 19:28:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We want to remove all legacy jobs here - so, let's just remove the jobs here instead of limiting them to older branches -  and backport your changes.."}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2017-12-31 20:48:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Andreas,

Yes, the plan is to remove the Neutron legacy jobs from this repo. I am going to backport https://review.openstack.org/#/c/525345/ to Pike and Ocata. However, while those cherry picks merge, we don't want patches to Neutron's master branch to have to go through double the normal number of jobs. That is why in the interim, I want the legacy jobs in this repo only to be executed for the stable branches."}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-01-03 19:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-01-03 19:24:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For the record, we are landing the master neutron patch adding new jobs there; it would be really helpful for gate to clean up duplicates before we backport the master patch to stable branches.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-03 20:42:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Other projects merged the addition in their repo, then a change to remove from project-config, then backported to stable - instead of pushing multiple reviews through project-config.'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-01-04 00:02:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Other projects probably don't care that much about stable branches to rip off jobs without replacement?"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2018-01-04 00:45:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-04 05:06:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

the other projects quickly merge the backports and tell reviewers to not approve other changes.'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-01-04 05:30:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Cherrypicks are: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/531070/ and https://review.openstack.org/#/c/531071/'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-04 05:33:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Miguel, now the depends-on on this one blocks until those cherry-picks are in...

Either remove the depends-on here - or let's merge the cherry-picks and rework this change to remove the jobs everywhere"}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-01-04 16:32:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-01-04 16:33:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Removed Depends-on tag from commit message'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-01-04 17:27:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Since we now have all backports lined up, maybe we should follow the advice of Andreas and land those first, then remove those templates completely.'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-01-04 17:42:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

OK, cool. Will re-purpose this patchset to remove the definitions'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-01-05 18:33:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-01-05 18:37:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-05 18:48:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-05 18:49:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

Please provide a patch against openstack-zuul-jobs to remove the now unused legacy job definitions. Once that one is up, I'll +2 again."}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-01-05 20:53:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-05 21:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-01-05 21:46:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9061, 'date': '2018-01-07 19:23:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/531070/ needs a rebase for this to land'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-01-09 16:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-01-10 06:53:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-11 13:10:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow+1

dependency merged'}]

commit_message:
Remove Neutron legacy jobs definition

Legacy jobs in the check and gate queues are being moved to the Neutron
repo in [1]. As a consequence, this change removes most of the Neutron
legacy jobs definition in this repo.

[1] I2cfa6030cb0826665d48d2c5e73f29401b6c1f4b

Needed-By: I6d4b8c85789ce340e74ba359108121a6912f5d3e
Depends-On: I2cfa6030cb0826665d48d2c5e73f29401b6c1f4b
Change-Id: I03e11dbc6d25380d2196e7d5baafba6d2116a570

Translate networks and subnet in cluster template

Translate 'external_network', 'fixed_network', 'fixed_subnet' in
cluster template from name to id.
Closes-Bug: #1719493

Change-Id: I78670cb4d394597b36c43d53f0f8094cb8bd285a

check and gate jobs

commit_message:
Consume tempest CLIClient keystone v3 support

tempest 17.1.0 added keystone v3 support to CLIClient and
we no longer need a workaround for keystone v3 func tests.

Change-Id: Ib32b5f82be938cd5213f6d71a0bf03cc1804587d
Related-Bug: #1721553
Related-Bug: #1719687

commit_message:
Fix the incorrect git.openstack.org source URL

Current pre-filled information contains incorrect git.openstack.org
source URL, please see this bug description. According to here[1],
we should set the giturl in the "conf.py" file.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstackdocstheme/blob/a5ceb6f15d3d0a177efd016aad5e148d42f50247/openstackdocstheme/theme/openstackdocs/script_footer.html#L43

Depends-on: I772a66de4680ba73ed79f8ea5481d6900f71fa82
Change-Id: Idc217fdddbdcc4b8bdab8850a40e807acdc23518
Closes-Bug: #1732630

subject: Add includes method to ShardRange
messages:
[{'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-01-03 11:17:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-03 18:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Something like

 diff --git a/swift/common/utils.py b/swift/common/utils.py
 index a18199a5c..9b0aa18ef 100644
 --- a/swift/common/utils.py
 +++ b/swift/common/utils.py
 @@ -4465,7 +4465,7 @@ class ShardRange(object):
          if self.entire_namespace():
              return True
          return ((self.lower == other.lower or other.lower in self) and
 -                (other.upper and other.upper in self))
 +                (self.upper == other.upper or other.upper and other.upper in self))
  
      def newer(self, other):
          if self._timestamp:
 diff --git a/test/unit/common/test_utils.py b/test/unit/common/test_utils.py
 index 3125455a5..707c2e675 100644
 --- a/test/unit/common/test_utils.py
 +++ b/test/unit/common/test_utils.py
 @@ -6926,9 +6926,14 @@ class TestShardRange(unittest.TestCase):
          e_to_l = utils.ShardRange('a/e-l', ts, 'e', 'l')
          k_to_t = utils.ShardRange('a/k-t', ts, 'k', 't')
          p_to_ = utils.ShardRange('a/p-', ts, 'p', '')
 +        t_to_ = utils.ShardRange('a/t-', ts, 't', '')
          entire = utils.ShardRange('a/all', ts, '', '')
  
          self.assertTrue(entire.includes(entire))
 +        self.assertTrue(d_to_t.includes(d_to_t))
 +        self.assertTrue(_to_h.includes(_to_h))
 +        self.assertTrue(p_to_.includes(p_to_))
 +
          self.assertTrue(entire.includes(_to_h))
          self.assertTrue(entire.includes(d_to_t))
          self.assertTrue(entire.includes(p_to_))
 @@ -6936,12 +6941,14 @@ class TestShardRange(unittest.TestCase):
          self.assertTrue(d_to_t.includes(d_to_k))
          self.assertTrue(d_to_t.includes(e_to_l))
          self.assertTrue(d_to_t.includes(k_to_t))
 +        self.assertTrue(p_to_.includes(t_to_))
  
          self.assertFalse(_to_h.includes(d_to_t))
          self.assertFalse(p_to_.includes(d_to_t))
          self.assertFalse(k_to_t.includes(d_to_k))
          self.assertFalse(d_to_k.includes(e_to_l))
          self.assertFalse(k_to_t.includes(e_to_l))
 +        self.assertFalse(t_to_.includes(p_to_))
  
          self.assertFalse(_to_h.includes(entire))
          self.assertFalse(p_to_.includes(entire))

seems like it'd help, but I wonder if we can make that return statement a little easier to reason about."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-01-03 19:17:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-01-04 10:14:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-01-04 16:22:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-04 23:03:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-01-05 10:27:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-01-08 03:58:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

This could be rolled into __contains__ if we add an 

  isinstance(other, ShardRange):
      return self.includes(other)

But that isn't something that's really a blocker, so something we _need_ to do."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-01-10 17:34:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-01-10 17:36:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

I reordered my chain so that this could be merged - already had +A on the identical patchset 4'}]

recheck'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-01-10 16:49:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think the problem here is that the same outcome - the error exit code - can arise from two possibilities. One is when we print a ring that is legitimately empty, and two is when we do something to that ring (like attempt to rebalance), and it blows up. Would that resolve our problem if the builder only exited with an error if the exceptions.EmptyRingError was caught? Or does Tripple-O try these erroneous operations too?'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-10 17:50:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

IDK, I think this is a reasonable change. It only affect the default (display) command, and returns us to previous behavior (ignoring the more-or-less-undefined behavior that was the traceback from bug 1737068)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-10 17:53:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Change exit code when displaying empty rings

Displaying an empty ring should not be an error, thus
changing the exit code back to the former value of 0.

Closes-Bug: 1742417
Change-Id: I779c30cff1b4d24483f993221a8c6d944b7ae98d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-03 05:11:12.000000000', 'message': 'Show devices marked as deleted on empty rings

This is a follow up patch to 530258 which will show
extra infromation on empty rings.

This patch goes one step further. On a completely empty ring:

  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder create  8 3 1
  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder
  my.builder, build version 0, id 33b4e117056340feae7d40430180c6bb
  256 partitions, 3.000000 replicas, 0 regions, 0 zones, 0 devices, 0.00 balance, 0.00 dispersion
  The minimum number of hours before a partition can be reassigned is 1 (0:00:00 remaining)
  The overload factor is 0.00% (0.000000)
  Ring file my.ring.gz not found, probably it hasn't been written yet
  Devices:   id region zone ip address:port replication ip:port  name weight partitions balance flags meta
  There are no devices in this ring

It will still start the device list and then say no devices.. Why. let's
see what happens now on an empty ring with devices still marked as
deleted:

  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder add r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010/sdb1 1
  Device d0r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb1_"" with 1.0 weight got id 0
  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder add r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010/sdb2 1
  Device d1r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb2_"" with 1.0 weight got id 1
  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder remove r1z1-127.0.0.1
  Matched more than one device:
      d0r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb1_""
      d1r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb2_""

commit_message:
Show devices marked as deleted on empty rings

This is a follow up patch to 530258 which will show
extra infromation on empty rings.

This patch goes one step further. On a completely empty ring:

  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder create  8 3 1
  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder
  my.builder, build version 0, id 33b4e117056340feae7d40430180c6bb
  256 partitions, 3.000000 replicas, 0 regions, 0 zones, 0 devices, 0.00 balance, 0.00 dispersion
  The minimum number of hours before a partition can be reassigned is 1 (0:00:00 remaining)
  The overload factor is 0.00% (0.000000)
  Ring file my.ring.gz not found, probably it hasn't been written yet
  Devices:   id region zone ip address:port replication ip:port  name weight partitions balance flags meta
  There are no devices in this ring, or all devices have been deleted

It will still start the device list and then say no devices.. Why. let's
see what happens now on an empty ring with devices still marked as
deleted:

  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder add r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010/sdb1 1
  Device d0r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb1_"" with 1.0 weight got id 0
  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder add r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010/sdb2 1
  Device d1r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb2_"" with 1.0 weight got id 1
  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder remove r1z1-127.0.0.1
  Matched more than one device:
      d0r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb1_""
      d1r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb2_""
  Are you sure you want to remove these 2 devices? (y/N) y
  d0r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb1_"" marked for removal and will be removed next rebalance.
  d1r1z1-127.0.0.1:6010R127.0.0.1:6010/sdb2_"" marked for removal and will be removed next rebalance.

  $ swift-ring-builder my.builder
  my.builder, build version 4, id 33b4e117056340feae7d40430180c6bb
  256 partitions, 3.000000 replicas, 1 regions, 1 zones, 2 devices, 0.00 balance, 0.00 dispersion
  The minimum number of hours before a partition can be reassigned is 1 (0:00:00 remaining)
  The overload factor is 0.00% (0.000000)
  Ring file my.ring.gz not found, probably it hasn't been written yet
  Devices:   id region zone ip address:port replication ip:port  name weight partitions balance flags meta
              0      1    1  127.0.0.1:6010      127.0.0.1:6010  sdb1 0.00          0    0.00   DEL
              1      1    1  127.0.0.1:6010      127.0.0.1:6010  sdb2 0.00          0    0.00   DEL
  There are no devices in this ring, or all devices have been deleted

Now even when all devices are removed we can still see them as they are still there, only marked as deleted.

Change-Id: Ib39f734deb67ad50bcdad5333cba716161a47e95

commit_message:
Fix barbicanclient deprecation

Use barbicanclient.v1.{containers,secrets} since they
are moved to the v1 directory.

UserWarning: The containers module is moved to barbicanclient/v1
directory, direct import of barbicanclient.containers will be
deprecated. Please import barbicanclient.v1.containers instead.

Change-Id: I0104b71a6977539a5b922e373982a3d453631d5a
Closes-Bug: #1737145

commit_message:
Fix Usage of cliff commandmanager

Set namespace to "magnum" when setting up cliff
commandmanager. Earlier None used to work but after
[1] and it's u-c release as cliff 2.10.0([2]) it requires
to be set as some string.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/522380/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/531764/

Change-Id: I036386d758a9351f053338f41a595fc030df5a33
Closes-Bug: #1741911
